author: konmaorg
title: DLT based student credential system
description: The performance tracking system of teachers and students is fragmented from primary to higher education.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal highlights the tremendous potential contribution of blockchains towards betterment of education. In this case, the Cardano blockchain will function as a Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) to identify and track performance of students and teachers thus addressing the need for foundational registry solutions stated by the challenge. 
The proposer refers to paper by Park (2021) which describes potential benefits of utilizing blockchains in the education sector of which employing blockchains for educational administration as according to the proposal can support authentication of identities, certificates, and records. 
However, while the assessor agrees that the idea proposed is good, the proposal could be much improved by emphasizing the greater benefit of supporting educational administration by blockchain. The assessor recognizes that particularly in developing countries, there is a need for a verifiable unified educational database due to difficulties in record keeping and to prevent fraud or misrepresentation of data. Mentioning the problems created by the the currently fragmented performance data could strengthen the argument towards the need for a Cardano supported identity and performance tracking Dapp.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers have divided the timeline into three phases beginning with the lobbying process to the Ministry of Education (3 months), the Dapp development (3 months) and then proceeding to the deployment and marketing of the Dapp (6 months). While the timeline as it is might be doable, delaying the development of the Dapp to the end of the lobbying process may result in a lost opportunity as the lobbying process might be helped by the presence of a working or at least an initial version of the Dapp. It is thus better to conduct the lobbying process at least parallel to the development process. This will also be a more effective use of time since development will begin early and the feedback from the lobbying process may improve the Dapp. 
The details of what is conducted in each phase and how it is conducted can be improved, especially for phase 1 and phase 3. At the proposal’s current condition, important questions remain :
-	Who will the team meet at the Ministry? Will he or she have the authority to decide or will the proposal be brought to a higher level? If it does need to be brought to higher authority, will three months be sufficient obtain a favorable decision?
-	What will ground team training consist of? Who will be the stakeholders the teams will meet to disseminate awareness of the program?
-	Which provinces will be prioritized early on? Is there a specific reason why?
The answers to these questions will also justify the size and division of the budget. The current breakdown of the budget is still very vague. Funds are divided into the three phases, but it is unclear what those funds be used for in each phase. A more detailed action plan can help clarify this. 
The proposers should realize that it is very likely that government institutions may meet the proposal with skepticism. Thus, the possibility of rejection or non-committal reception is likely. The proposers should prepare an alternative approach in anticipation of this. For example, the team may plan to then directly approach schools that can independently decide to buy in to the proposed Dapp, such as private schools. 
In regards to the team members present, while the assessor can deduce who will be responsible for each specific phase, the division of labor is not clearly stated in the proposal. The proposers should also describe previous projects and experiences of team members relevant to the proposal in addition to credentials presented in their LinkedIn profiles. Doing as such will reinforce the proposal and strengthen the reasoning of the feasibility of the plan.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposers specify the total number of schools and colleges onboard as a KPI for progress. However, it is not mentioned what can be categorized as “onboard”. Does it mean that performance records for all students and teachers are present in those institutions the dapp? Or is a partial population per school considered acceptable?
While indeed the proposal also mentions the number of active users on the dapp as a metric, it is also unclear what constitutes an active user. Are active users the number of individuals whose performance data is present and continually recorded? 
The last metric is also unclear as the measurement of “Dapp performance metrics” is also vague. What kind of performance metric will be considered? 
The timeline for the project proposed is 12 months. Meanwhile, their marketing and deployment phase is half that. With this in mind, the proposers have also not mentioned the how they wish to measure their KPIs and at what frequency as the timeline for deployment is short. 
The proposers envision success as the implementation of the solution at 15% of educational institutions in Sri Lanka in the first year. Will the first year include the lobbying and development phase? Or will the first year mean the first year since deployment and implementation? The proposers should clarify definitions and milestones set.

f6_assessments.q0: Developing a blockchain-based platform that protects students' and teachers' digital identities would reduce security risks and increase the use of blockchain and crypto in education. The thesis presented to take the reader to the proposal's main point is quite detailed and thorough. The proposer, on the other hand, claims that they must lobby the Education Ministry and propose the concept. This is frequently challenging and necessitates a well-thought-out strategy in order to be accepted. Because the proposer did not provide a solution in the proposal, I doubt the problem would be simple to solve. Despite the fact that the proposal recognizes this issue and includes it in the main challenge, as well as the uncertainty of blockchain and crypto regulation, they have not provided a convincing answer for it. I believe that a lack of certainty in the regulation of blockchain and crypto will result in the security of digital identities not being fully guaranteed. As a result, I propose that the proposal find a solution to the blockchain problem, and then submit an error-free proposal to the Education ministry. To ensure that this project gets accepted first, we must guarantee that we are prepared for any challenges that may arise.
f6_assessments.q1: According to the timeline, the proposal will take 12 months to complete. It is simple to follow the plan by dividing it into three phases and explicitly stating the work that must be completed in each phase. The first phase, lobbying with the Ministry of Education, will take three months, which is a reasonable amount of time and budget. If phase 1 is successful, phases 2 and 3 will be implemented. However, the proposer could go into further detail about what the executives will perform for each phase or for the entire project. Having a general idea of how many employees will work as planned can also help in better asseting the project. The proposer has a link that contains all of the team's information and is prepared to work in Sri Lanka on this project. In my perspective, the project has potential, and the team has the ability to properly implement the project.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer mentions three measures for success in this project, but does not specify how these three measures would be evaluated. For example, given the project's scope of schools within Sri Lanka, how many schools must be on board to be considered a success for the project? And what is the proposer's expectation for the number of active users after six months or every 3 months? These details are critical for the community to track progress, and they must be presented in a clear and concise manner. The project's auditability is difficult because there is no mention of the security risk of storing students' and teachers' digital identities. The KPIs, on the other hand, are successful in aligning with the challenge setting. I am hoping that this project has a significant impact on National Building Dapps.

f6_assessments.q0:
I strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.

The proposers are opting for application of DLT to better manage the tracking performance and credentials of teachers and students with the aim of replacing the current fragmented system. 
 
The proposers gave statistical data of the education system in Sri Lanka, which country they propose to start the project with and once successful will expand to other developing countries. 
 
Assigning unique identity to  each students and teachers, about 5 million, the tracking system can be unified and better managed securely by using the DL technology providing traceability of students performance from primary to higher education. 
 
Once this is successfully  done, the impact would be that awareness of the technology would be increased and would raise the quest for more applications in other areas within the education of Sri Lankan government as well as in other departments. 
 
The proposers are not certain about  regulations on blockchain and crypto. They plan to lobby with the Ministry of Education on benefits of the proposed solution to mitigate this. 
 
Because of the large size of the database a large scale of resources need to be deployed. However they can work on phases, province by province.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers will work on 3 phases, spreading over 12 months with the last phase within 6 months. The main hurdle is getting the Ministry to agree to the proposal. The works involved are the time resources and this is the main portion in their total budget of 60000 USD. 
 
The personnel involved are provided.  Their experience, skills and expertise are needed for this project. In their plan however, I reckon that training the Education administration personnel on the use of the system is important and should have been discussed in the proposal. 
 
For that I agree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposers laid out the matrics but the goals are not set for each. 
 
However, they  target that 15% of the educational institutions would  implement the system in the first year and to reach the target of 75% in the second year; gives a good idea to measure the progress.
